text: Despite calls for including content on climate change and its effect on health in curricula across the spectrum of medical education, no widely used resource exists to guide residency training programs in this effort
label: academic

text: This lack of resources poses challenges for training program leaders seeking to incorporate evidence-based climate and health content into their curricula
label: academic

text: Climate change increases risks of heat-related illness, infections, asthma, mental health disorders, poor perinatal outcomes, adverse experiences from trauma and displacement, and other harms
label: academic

text: More numerous and increasingly dangerous natural disasters caused by climate change impair delivery of care by disrupting supply chains and compromising power supplies
label: academic

text: Graduating trainees face a knowledge gap in understanding, managing, and mitigating these many-faceted consequences of climate change, which-expected to intensify in coming decades-will influence both the health of their patients and the health care they deliver
label: academic

text: In this article, the authors propose a framework of climate change and health educational content for residents, including how climate change (1) harms health, (2) necessitates adaptation in clinical practice, and (3) undermines health care delivery
label: academic

text: The authors propose not only learning objectives linked to the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education core competencies for resident education, but also learning formats and assessment strategies in each content area
label: academic

text: They also present opportunities for implementation of climate and health education in residency training programs
label: academic

text: Including this content in residency education will better prepare doctors to deliver anticipatory guidance to at-risk patients, manage those experiencing climate-related health effects, and reduce care disruptions during climate-driven extreme weather events
label: academic

text: Climate change is increasing risks to human health and to the health systems that seek to protect the safety and well-being of populations
label: academic

text: Health authorities require information about current associations between health outcomes and weather or climate, vulnerable populations, projections of future risks and adaptation opportunities in order to reduce exposures, empower individuals to take needed protective actions and build climate-resilient health systems
label: academic

text: An increasing number of health authorities from local to national levels seek this information by conducting climate change and health vulnerability and adaptation assessments
label: academic

text: While assessments can provide valuable information to plan for climate change impacts, the results of many studies are not helping to build the global evidence-base of knowledge in this area
label: academic

text: They are also often not integrated into adaptation decision making, sometimes because the health sector is not involved in climate change policy making processes at the national level
label: academic

text: Significant barriers related to data accessibility, a limited number of climate and health models, uncertainty in climate projections, and a lack of funding and expertise, particularly in developing countries, challenge health authority efforts to conduct rigorous assessments and apply the findings
label: academic

text: This paper examines the evolution of climate change and health vulnerability and adaptation assessments, including guidance developed for such projects, the number of assessments that have been conducted globally and implementation of the findings to support health adaptation action
label: academic

text: Greater capacity building that facilitates assessments from local to national scales will support collaborative efforts to protect health from current climate hazards and future climate change
label: academic

text: Health sector officials will benefit from additional resources and partnership opportunities to ensure that evidence about climate change impacts on health is effectively translated into needed actions to build health resilience
label: academic

text: National and international assessments have drawn attention to the substantial economic risks of climate change
label: academic

text: The costs of climate-sensitive health outcomes responsive to meteorological or seasonal patterns are among the least studied of those risks
label: academic

text: In this article we describe how cost valuation analyses that relate climate-sensitive health outcomes to damages in economic terms can illuminate the costs of inaction on the climate crisis and the economic savings of addressing this problem
label: academic

text: We identify major challenges to expanding the application of climate-health valuation research and suggest solutions to overcome these obstacles to better characterize the burden of climate-sensitive health outcomes and health disparities
label: academic

text: The projected health and economic harms of climate-sensitive risks could be enormous if climate change continues to accelerate and communities are not prepared to reduce or prevent their impact
label: academic

text: Expanded valuation of climate-sensitive health outcomes can inform policies that slow climate change and promote stronger investments in health-protective climate change adaptation efforts
label: academic

text: Climate change is an emerging and growing field of practice for the international public health community
label: academic

text: As practitioners, researchers and policy-makers grapple with the local health impacts of climate change, there is an increasing need to clarify key terminology to support public health actors engage and respond in ways that promote intersectoral collaboration
label: academic

text: This contribution introduces the public health discourse on climate change, with a particular focus on its implications for health equity
label: academic

text: After defining key terms and existing adaptation practices, climate justice and assets-oriented inquiry into the intersectional determinants of health are discussed as future opportunities for addressing health equity in climate and health-related research and practice
label: academic

text: Significance More intense extreme events are projected under future climate change
label: academic

text: However, the impacts of climate extremes on future air quality and associated health implications are not well recognized and are rarely quantified in China, with an enormous health burden from air pollution
label: academic

text: Here, we estimate the climate-driven air pollution mortality in China and find that future climate change is likely to exacerbate air pollution mortality, largely influenced by the more intense extreme events such as stagnation events and heat waves
label: academic

text: Our analysis provides quantitative assessments and insights regarding the links between climate extremes, future air quality, and public health, suggesting that extreme weather events may be an important mechanism by which climate change will affect air quality, and especially fine particulate matter
label: academic

text: In recent years, air pollution has caused more than 1 million deaths per year in China, making it a major focus of public health efforts
label: academic

text: However, future climate change may exacerbate such human health impacts by increasing the frequency and duration of weather conditions that enhance air pollution exposure
label: academic

text: Here, we use a combination of climate, air quality, and epidemiological models to assess future air pollution deaths in a changing climate under Representative Concentration Pathway 4
label: academic

text: We find that, assuming pollution emissions and population are held constant at current levels, climate change would adversely affect future air quality for >85% of China’s population (∼55% of land area) by the middle of the century, and would increase by 3% and 4% the population-weighted average concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2
label: academic

text: 5) and ozone, respectively
label: academic

text: As a result, we estimate an additional 12,100 and 8,900 Chinese (95% confidence interval: 10,300 to 13,800 and 2,300 to 14,700, respectively) will die per year from PM2
label: academic

text: 5 and ozone exposure, respectively
label: academic

text: The important underlying climate mechanisms are changes in extreme conditions such as atmospheric stagnation and heat waves (contributing 39% and 6%, respectively, to the increase in mortality)
label: academic

text: Additionally, greater vulnerability of China’s aging population will further increase the estimated deaths from PM2
label: academic

text: 5 and ozone in 2050 by factors of 1 and 3, respectively
label: academic

text: Our results indicate that climate change and more intense extremes are likely to increase the risk of severe pollution events in China
label: academic

text: Managing air quality in China in a changing climate will thus become more challenging
label: academic

text: BackgroundGlobally, the response to climate change is gradually gaining momentum as the impacts of climate change unfold
label: academic

text: In South Africa, it is increasingly apparent that delays in responding to climate change over the past decades have jeopardized human life and livelihoods
label: academic

text: While slow progress with mitigation, especially in the energy sector, has garnered much attention, focus is now shifting to developing plans and systems to adapt to the impacts of climate change
label: academic

text: MethodsWe applied systematic review methods to assess progress with climate change adaptation in the health sector in South Africa
label: academic

text: This case study provides useful lessons which could be applied in other countries in the African region, or globally
label: academic

text: We reviewed the literature indexed in PubMed and Web of Science, together with relevant grey literature
label: academic

text: We included articles describing adaptation interventions to reduce the impact of climate change on health in South Africa
label: academic

text: All study designs were eligible
label: academic

text: Data from included articles and grey literature were summed thematically
label: academic

text: ResultsOf the 820 publications screened, 21 were included, together with an additional xx papers
label: academic

text: Very few studies presented findings of an intervention or used high-quality research designs
label: academic

text: Several policy frameworks for climate change have been developed at national and local government levels
label: academic

text: These, however, pay little attention to health concerns and the specific needs of vulnerable groups
label: academic

text: Systems for forecasting extreme weather, and tracking malaria and other infections appear well established
label: academic

text: Yet, there is little evidence about the country’s preparedness for extreme weather events, or the ability of the already strained health system to respond to these events
label: academic

text: Seemingly, few adaptation measures have taken place in occupational and other settings
label: academic

text: To date, little attention has been given to climate change in training curricula for health workers
label: academic

text: ConclusionsOverall, the volume and quality of research is disappointing, and disproportionate to the threat posed by climate change in South Africa
label: academic

text: This is surprising given that the requisite expertise for policy advocacy, identifying effective interventions and implementing systems-based approaches rests within the health sector
label: academic

text: More effective use of data, a traditional strength of health professionals, could support adaptation and promote accountability of the state
label: academic

text: With increased health-sector leadership, climate change could be reframed as predominately a health issue, one necessitating an urgent, adequately-resourced response
label: academic

text: Such a shift in South Africa, but also beyond the country, may play a key role in accelerating climate change adaptation and mitigation
label: academic

text: Policy action in the coming decade will be crucial to achieving globally agreed upon goals to decarbonize the economy and build resilience to a warmer, more extreme climate
label: academic

text: Public health has an essential role in climate planning and action: “Co-benefits” to health help underpin greenhouse gas reduction strategies, while safeguarding health—particularly of the most vulnerable—is a frontline local adaptation goal
label: academic

text: Using the structure of the core functions and essential services (CFES), we reviewed the literature documenting the evolution of public health’s role in climate change action since the 2009 launch of the US CDC Climate and Health Program
label: academic

text: We found that the public health response to climate change has been promising in the area of assessment (monitoring climate hazards, diagnosing health status, assessing vulnerability); mixed in the area of policy development (mobilizing partnerships, mitigation and adaptation activities); and relatively weak in assurance (communication, workforce development and evaluation)
label: academic

text: We suggest that the CFES model remains important, but is not aligned with three concepts—governance, implementation and adjustment—that have taken on increasing importance
label: academic

text: Adding these concepts to the model can help ensure that public health fulfills its potential as a proactive partner fully integrated into climate policy planning and action in the coming decade
label: academic

text: Background The World Health Organization emphasized that climate change is a significant and emerging threat to public health, especially in lower income populations and tropical/subtropical countries
label: academic

text: However, people in Asia and Africa were the least likely to perceive global warming as a threat
label: academic

text: In Vietnam, little research has been conducted concerning the perceptions of effects of climate change on human health
label: academic

text: Objective The aim of this study was to explore the perceptions on climate change and its impact on human health among people in Hanoi
label: academic

text: Design We applied a combined quantitative and qualitative approach to study perceptions on climate change among people in Hanoi
label: academic

text: A total of 1,444 people were recruited, including 754 people living in non-slum areas and 690 people living in slum areas of Hanoi
label: academic

text: A structured questionnaire was used to collect quantitative data on their perceptions
label: academic

text: In a parallel qualitative study, two focus group discussions and 12 in-depth interviews (IDs) were carried out involving 24 people from both slum and non-slum areas
label: academic

text: Results The majority of the respondents in the study had heard about climate change and its impact on human health (79
label: academic

text: 3 and 70
label: academic

text: 1% in non-slum and slum areas, respectively)
label: academic

text: About one third of the respondents reported that members of their family had experienced illness in the recent summer and winter compared to the same seasons 5 years ago
label: academic

text: The most common symptoms reported during hot weather were headaches, fatigue, and dizziness; hypertension and other cardiovascular diseases were also reported
label: academic

text: During cold weather, people reported experiencing cough, fever, and influenza, as well as pneumonia and emerging infectious diseases such as dengue and Japanese encephalitis
label: academic

text: Conclusions The observed high level of awareness on the links between climate change and human health may help to increase the success of the National Prevention Program on Climate Change
label: academic

text: Moreover, understanding the concerns of the people may help policy makers to develop and implement effective and sustainable adaptation measures for Hanoi City as well as for Vietnam as a whole
label: academic

text: The Environmental Effects Assessment Panel of the Montreal Protocol under the United Nations Environment Programme evaluates effects on the environment and human health that arise from changes in the stratospheric ozone layer and concomitant variations in ultraviolet (UV) radiation at the Earth’s surface
label: academic

text: The current update is based on scientific advances that have accumulated since our last assessment (Photochem and Photobiol Sci 20(1):1–67, 2021)
label: academic

text: We also discuss how climate change affects stratospheric ozone depletion and ultraviolet radiation, and how stratospheric ozone depletion affects climate change
label: academic

text: The resulting interlinking effects of stratospheric ozone depletion, UV radiation, and climate change are assessed in terms of air quality, carbon sinks, ecosystems, human health, and natural and synthetic materials
label: academic

text: We further highlight potential impacts on the biosphere from extreme climate events that are occurring with increasing frequency as a consequence of climate change
label: academic

text: These and other interactive effects are examined with respect to the benefits that the Montreal Protocol and its Amendments are providing to life on Earth by controlling the production of various substances that contribute to both stratospheric ozone depletion and climate change
label: academic

text: Coastal areas have been increasingly affected by human activities, marine pollution and climate change are among the most important pressures affecting these environments
label: academic

text: Human-induced pressures occur in a cumulative way and generate additive, antagonistic or synergistic effects
label: academic

text: Knowledge on synergistic effects is crucial to coastal zone management, since they may imply a change in human uses of these systems, as well as dedicated action plans in order to reduce hazards and environmental risks
label: academic

text: In this work, we provide an overview of the available literature on synergistic effects between climate change and chemical pollution, and discuss current knowledge, methodological approaches, and research gaps and needs
label: academic

text: Interactions between these two pressures may be climate change dominant (climate change leads to an increase in contaminant exposure or toxicity) or contaminant-dominant (chemical exposure leads to an increase in climate change susceptibility), but the mechanistic drivers of such processes are not well known
label: academic

text: Results from a few meta-analyses studies and reviews showed that synergistic interactions tend to be more frequent compared to additive and antagonistic ones
label: academic

text: However, most of the studies are individual-based and assess the cumulative effects of a few contaminants individually in laboratory settings together with few climate variables, particularly temperature and pH
label: academic

text: Nevertheless, a wide diversity of contaminants have already been individually tested, spanning from metals, persistent organic pollutants and, more recently, emergent pollutants
label: academic

text: Population and community based approaches are less frequent but have generated very interesting and more holistic perspectives
label: academic

text: Methodological approaches are quite diverse, from laboratory studies to mesocosm and field studies, or based on statistical or modelling tools, each with their own potential and limitations
label: academic

text: More holistic comparisons integrating several pressures and their combinations and a multitude of habitats, taxa, life-stages, among others, are needed, as well as insights from meta-analyses and systematic reviews
label: academic

text: Human-induced climate change, with such rapid and continuing global-scale warming, is historically unprecedented and signifies that human pressures on Earth's life-supporting natural systems now exceed the planet's bio-geo-capacity
label: academic

text: The risks from climate change to health and survival in populations are diverse, as are the social and political ramifications
label: academic

text: Although attributing observed health changes in a population to the recent climatic change is difficult, a coherent pattern of climate- and weather-associated changes is now evident in many regions of the world
label: academic

text: The risks impinge unevenly, especially on poorer and vulnerable regions, and are amplified by pre-existing high rates of climate-sensitive diseases and conditions
label: academic

text: If, as now appears likely, the world warms by 3-5oC by 2100, the health consequences, directly and via massive social and economic disruption, will be severe
label: academic

text: The health sector has an important message to convey, comparing the health risks and benefits of enlightened action to avert climate change and to achieve sustainable ways of living versus the self-interested or complacent inaction
label: academic

text: Background: Abundant historical evidence demonstrates how environmental changes can affect social stability and, in turn, human health
label: academic

text: A rapidly growing body of literature, largely from political science and economics, is examining the potential for and consequences associated with social instability related to current climate change
label: academic

text: However, comparatively little of this research incorporates the effects on human health or the role of health systems in influencing the magnitude and types of instability that could occur
label: academic

text: Objective: The objective of this commentary is to articulate a conceptual framework incorporating health outcomes and health systems into theorized and observed linkages between climate change and social instability, illustrating in particular the health effects of natural resource shortages, infectious disease outbreaks, and migration
label: academic

text: Discussion: Although increasing evidence exists that climate change, health, and social instability are related, key questions remain about the pathways linking these factors, as well as the magnitude, causality, and directionality of relationships across spatial and temporal scales
label: academic

text: Models seeking to explain and predict climate-related social unrest should incorporate the many linkages between climate change, human health, and social instability
label: academic

text: Members of the environmental health research community should work closely with those in the political science and economics communities to help deepen understandings of climate-related stressors and shocks that affect instability and worsen health outcomes
label: academic

text: Climate Change — A Health Emergency The effects of climate disruption are fundamentally health issues
label: academic

text: As physicians, we have a special responsibility to safeguard health and alleviate suffering, and individual actions are far from enough to address the challenge we collectively face
label: academic

text: The MJA–Lancet Countdown on health and climate change was established in 2017 and produced its first Australian national assessment in 2018
label: academic

text: It examined 41 indicators across five broad domains: climate change impacts, exposures and vulnerability; adaptation, planning and resilience for health; mitigation actions and health co‐benefits; economics and finance; and public and political engagement
label: academic

text: It found that, overall, Australia is vulnerable to the impacts of climate change on health, and that policy inaction in this regard threatens Australian lives
label: academic

text: In this report we present the 2019 update
label: academic

text: We track progress on health and climate change in Australia across the same five broad domains and many of the same indicators as in 2018
label: academic

text: A number of new indicators are introduced this year, including one focused on wildfire exposure, and another on engagement in health and climate change in the corporate sector
label: academic

text: Several of the previously reported indicators are not included this year, either due to their discontinuation by the parent project, the Lancet Countdown, or because insufficient new data were available for us to meaningfully provide an update to the indicator
label: academic

text: In a year marked by an Australian federal election in which climate change featured prominently, we find mixed progress on health and climate change in this country
label: academic

text: There has been progress in renewable energy generation, including substantial employment increases in this sector
label: academic

text: There has also been some progress at state and local government level
label: academic

text: However, there continues to be no engagement on health and climate change in the Australian federal Parliament, and Australia performs poorly across many of the indicators in comparison to other developed countries; for example, it is one of the world's largest net exporters of coal and its electricity generation from low carbon sources is low
label: academic

text: We also find significantly increasing exposure of Australians to heatwaves and, in most states and territories, continuing elevated suicide rates at higher temperatures
label: academic

text: We conclude that Australia remains at significant risk of declines in health due to climate change, and that substantial and sustained national action is urgently required in order to prevent this
label: academic

text: We examined two of humanity's present-day challenges, climate change and chronic diseases, in relation to the co-benefits that green spaces provide to human health and the environment
label: academic

text: The reduction of several chronic diseases and associated symptoms, including anxiety, obesity and cardiovascular disease, has been associated with the presence of and access to green space
label: academic

text: Green spaces also contribute to a number of environmental health benefits and have been shown to reduce the likelihood of flooding, improve air quality and provide cooling and shade
label: academic

text: These co-benefits address both the symptoms of several chronic diseases and associated risk factors along with the environmental and health impacts of climate change
label: academic

text: This article explores how to maximize the co-benefits of green spaces through two examples of multi-sectoral collaborations
label: academic

text: With these two examples, we have provided a model of collective collaboration that aims to address complex issues, such as climate change and chronic diseases, through the common intervention of green spaces
label: academic

text: Climate change is the defining global public health threat of the twenty-first century (Whitmee et al
label: academic

text: , 2015; WHO, 2018; Watts et al
label: academic

text: , 2019) and has profound implications for nearly every aspect of health
label: academic

text: The ongoing COVID-19 crisis is causing unprecedented disruptions to health systems, but climate change will have even greater—much greater—consequences
label: academic

text: Yet health policy and systems researchers largely continue to ignore and overlook climate change
label: academic

text: This is a critical oversight
label: academic

text: Countries with the greatest vulnerability to climate change have the least developed health systems (Salas and Jha, 2019), and climate change will further compound and exacerbate existing inequalities (Costello et al
label: academic

text: Health policy and systems research (HPSR) is well positioned to accelerate the needed response and transformation (Peters, 2018)
label: academic

text: HPSR could make countless contributions to address the climate challenge
label: academic

text: We highlight three interlinked reasons, which should motivate the HPSR community to prioritize a focus on climate change
label: academic

text: First, HPSR is crucial to understanding the impact and implications of climate change
label: academic

text: HPSR seeks to analyse how different actors interact in policy and implementation processes to improve health outcomes
label: academic

text: It draws on a blend of public health, economics, sociology, anthropology, political science and epidemiology and can serve as a multidisciplinary bridge to these various fields
label: academic

text: HPSR seeks to analyse how health systems respond and adapt to health policies, and how health policies can shape and be shaped by health systems and broader determinants of health like climate change (AHPSR, 2007)
label: academic

text: The interdisciplinary nature of HPSR makes it well positioned to tackle the complexity of climate change and can improve the analysis of linkages between health and climate
label: academic

text: Until now, the climate change and health literature have focused on infectious diseases (Hosking and Campbell-Lendrum, 2012), along with deaths and injuries from extreme weather events, the adverse health effects of extreme heat (Hosking and Campbell-Lendrum, 2012), and risks of under-nutrition due to declines in food yields (Friel et al
label: academic

text: , 2011; Hosking and Campbell-Lendrum, 2012; Xie et al
label: academic

text: These studies show how climate change affects health outcomes; HPSR could augment ongoing efforts and widen this understanding by applying a systems approach
label: academic

text: There is an urgent need to take a broader health systems and health policies perspective; this is the role of the HPSR community
label: academic

text: Researchers can help policymakers appreciate, anticipate and work to prevent the effects of climate change on human health and well-being
label: academic

text: For example, most efforts to achieve primary health care (PHC) do not sufficiently consider the implications of the climate crisis (Kadandale et al
label: academic

text: There is a need to revise the discourse, policy and practice on efforts to achieve PHC, but also universal health coverage to include explicit consideration of climate change and its health effects
label: academic

text: Second, HPSR is essential to developing and designing both climate change mitigation and adaptation policies within the health sector
label: academic

text: It can also help policymakers appreciate how to implement these policies
label: academic

text: The emergent literature on health systems and climate change considers adaptation (Mayhew and Hanefeld, 2014), but there is comparatively limited work on mitigation, though these will vary by context, with mitigation policies needed urgently in highincome, high-emitting countries and adaptation policies needed in countries with relatively fewer emissions, both approaches are crucial
label: academic

text: A 2019 World Health Organization (WHO) survey found that knowledge of the health implications of climate change is shaping policymaking, however, additional financial or human resources are not being allocated to meet the challenge (WHO, 2019)
label: academic

text: Adequate financial resources, including from climate change funding sources, have not shifted to health budgets
label: academic

text: For example, the same survey identified financing as one the main barriers with only 9% of National Adaptation Plans for Health (H-NAP) being fully resourced (WHO, 2019)
label: academic

text: Addressing this requires strengthening health policymakers’, health workers’ and health institutions’ capacities to adapt to and
label: academic

text: ABSTRACT Health systems and infrastructure have been suggested to be overwhelmed by the large-scale public health risks from climate change
label: academic

text: With weak health systems, the impact is estimated to be far greater in developing countries, which are already over-burdened with poor health outcomes
label: academic

text: Yet, there is limited knowledge about the preparedness and capacities of health institutions and professionals in developing countries to respond to climate change health risks
label: academic

text: Drawing from the World Health Organization’s framework on health system capacities, effective response and emergency preparedness, and using mixed methods research design, we examined capacities and preparedness of public health professionals in Ghana to manage climate change-health risks and emergencies
label: academic

text: Qualitative interviews (n = 20) and quantitative surveys (n = 99) were conducted with health professionals in Savelugu-Nanton and Ada East Districts in Ghana
label: academic

text: The study found that, capacity and preparedness of health professionals and institutions to respond to climate change related health emergencies were weak in the study districts
label: academic

text: Based on our findings, we recommend the development and implementation of a comprehensive policy on climate change and health to build capacities of health institutions and professionals, improve climate change health research, and increase funding to climate change programmes and activities in local communities
label: academic

text: Reliable estimates of future health impacts due to climate change are needed to inform and contribute to the design of efficient adaptation and mitigation strategies
label: academic

text: However, projecting health burdens associated to specific environmental stressors is a challenging task because of the complex risk patterns and inherent uncertainty of future climate scenarios
label: academic

text: These assessments involve multidisciplinary knowledge, requiring expertise in epidemiology, statistics, and climate science, among other subjects
label: academic

text: Here, we present a methodologic framework to estimate future health impacts under climate change scenarios based on a defined set of assumptions and advanced statistical techniques developed in time-series analysis in environmental epidemiology
label: academic

text: The proposed methodology is illustrated through a step-by-step hands-on tutorial structured in well-defined sections that cover the main methodological steps and essential elements
label: academic

text: Each section provides a thorough description of each step, along with a discussion on available analytical options and the rationale on the choices made in the proposed framework
label: academic

text: The illustration is complemented with a practical example of study using real-world data and a series of R scripts included as Supplementary Digital Content; http://links
label: academic

text: com/EDE/B504, which facilitates its replication and extension on other environmental stressors, outcomes, study settings, and projection scenarios
label: academic

text: Users should critically assess the potential modeling alternatives and modify the framework and R code to adapt them to their research on health impact projections
label: academic

text: Climate change is known to affect Pacific Island nations in a variety of ways
label: academic

text: One of them is by increasing the vulnerability of human health induced by various climate change impacts, which pose an additional burden to the already distressed health systems in the region
label: academic

text: This paper explores the associations between climate change and human health on the one hand, and outlines some of the health care challenges posed by a changing climate on the other
label: academic

text: In particular, it describes the links between climate variations and the emergence of climate-sensitive infectious diseases, such as the mosquito-borne diseases dengue, chikungunya, and Zika
label: academic

text: The paper also presents a summary of the key findings of the research initiatives Climate Change and Prevalence Study of ZIKA Virus Diseases in Fiji and the findings from the World Mosquito Program as two examples of public health action in the Pacific region
label: academic

text: Climate change worry involves primarily verbal-linguistic thoughts about the changes that may occur in the climate system and the possible effects of these changes
label: academic

text: Such worry is one of several possible psychological responses (e
label: academic

text: , fear, anxiety, depression, and trauma) to climate change
label: academic

text: Within this article, the psychometric development of the ten-item Climate Change Worry Scale (CCWS) is detailed in three studies
label: academic

text: The scale was developed to assess proximal worry about climate change rather than social or global impacts
label: academic

text: Study 1 provided evidence that the CCWS items were internally consistent, constituted a single factor, and that the facture structure of the items was invariant for men and women
label: academic

text: The results from Study 1 also indicated a good fit with a Rasch model of the items
label: academic

text: Study 2 affirmed the internal consistency of the CCWS items and indicated that peoples’ responses to the measure were temporally stable over a two-week test–retest interval (r = 0
label: academic

text: Study 3 provided support for the convergent and divergent validity of the CCWS through its pattern of correlations with several established clinical and weather-related measures
label: academic

text: The limitations of the studies and the possible uses of the CCWS were discussed
label: academic

text: The current work represents a starting point
label: academic

text: This study aimed to measure the knowledge and perceptions of medical, public health, and nursing students about climate change and its impacts, and to identify associations between the knowledge and perceptions
label: academic

text: Data were from a nationwide cross-sectional survey of 1387 students sampled in five different regional universities in China (April–May 2017)
label: academic

text: The knowledge and perceptions of the participants were collected by self-administered questionnaires
label: academic

text: We found that most respondents believed that climate change is generally “bad” (83%) and bad for human health (88%), while 67% believed that climate change is controllable
label: academic

text: The vast majority of respondents acknowledged illness conditions resulting from poor air quality (95%), heat stress (93%), and extreme weather events (91%) as potential impacts of climate change
label: academic

text: Nevertheless, only 39% recognized malnutrition as a consequence of food deprivation resulting from climate change
label: academic

text: Around 58% of respondents could correctly identify the causes of climate change
label: academic

text: The knowledge of the causes of climate change was not associated with the ability to recognize the health consequences of climate change
label: academic

text: However, the knowledge of causes of climate change was a significant predictor of increased awareness of the negative impacts of climate change between the medical and nursing students, although this was not the case among their public health counterparts
label: academic

text: Poor knowledge about the causes of climate change is evident among students in China
label: academic

text: They are able to recognize the direct links between weather events and health, but less likely to understand the consequences involving complicated pathways
label: academic

text: Research and training into the underlying mechanisms of health impacts of climate change needs to be strengthened
label: academic

text: Climate change poses a range of current and future health risks that health professionals need to understand, track, and manage
label: academic

text: However, conventional monitoring and evaluation (M&E) as practiced in the health sector, including the use of indicators, does not adequately serve this purpose
label: academic

text: Improved indicators are needed in three broad categories: (1) vulnerability and exposure to climate-related hazards; (2) current impacts and projected risks; and (3) adaptation processes and health system resilience
label: academic

text: These indicators are needed at the population level and at the health systems level (including clinical care and public health)
label: academic

text: Selected indicators must be sensitive, valid, and useful
label: academic

text: And they must account for uncertainties about the magnitude and pattern of climate change; the broad range of upstream drivers of climate-sensitive health outcomes; and the complexities of adaptation itself, including institutional learning and knowledge management to inform iterative risk management
label: academic

text: Barriers and constraints to implementing such indicators must be addressed, and lessons learned need to be added to the evidence base
label: academic

text: This paper describes an approach to climate and health indicators, including characteristics of the indicators, implementation, and research needs
label: academic

text: Climate is one of many factors with the potential to alter disease states and is expected to exert an overwhelming negative effect on the health of humans and animals (Rabinowitz and Conti, 2013)
label: academic

text: In addition, several studies suggested that the increase of temperature might reduce mortality and/or improve health and welfare related aspects in humans and livestock living in geographic areas with cold winters (Ballester et al
label: academic

text: , 2011; Rose et al
label: academic

text: The effect of climate change on animal health may be either direct or indirect (Figure 1) and may be due primarily to changes in environmental conditions, which include air temperature, relative humidity, precipitation, and frequency and magnitude of extreme events (i
label: academic

text: , heat waves, severe droughts, extreme precipitation events, and coastal floods)
label: academic

text: Although this article focuses on the effects of environmental factors, it should be noted that factors leading to the effects of climate change on health are extremely complex, involving not only environmental forces, but also ecological and social aspects, economical interests, and individual and community behaviors (Forastiere, 2010)

text: Climate change is increasing risks to the mental health of Canadians
label: academic

text: Impacts from a changing climate may outstrip the ability of Canadians and their health-sustaining institutions to adapt effectively and could increase poor mental health outcomes, particularly amongst those most marginalized in society
label: academic

text: A scoping review of literature published during 2000–2017 explored risks, impacts, and vulnerabilities related to climate change and mental health
label: academic

text: In this commentary, the authors present a new assessment of evidence from this scoping review and highlight factors that influence the capacity to adapt to the mental health consequences of a changing climate
label: academic

text: Findings from this assessment reveal eleven key factors that influence the capacity to adapt: social capital; sense of community; government assistance; access to resources; community preparedness; intersectoral/transdisciplinary collaboration; vulnerability and adaptation assessments; communication and outreach; mental health literacy; and culturally relevant resources
label: academic

text: Attention to these factors by Canadian decision makers can support proactive and effective management of the mental health consequences of climate change
label: academic

text: BackgroundThe adverse health impacts of climate change are increasing on a global level
label: academic

text: However, knowledge about climate change and health is still unavailable to many global citizens, in particular on adaptation measures and co-benefits of health mitigation
label: academic

text: Educational technologies, such as massive open online courses (MOOCs), may have a high potential for providing access to information about climate change links to health for a global audience
label: academic

text: Main bodyWe developed three MOOCs addressing the link between climate change and health to take advantage of the methodology’s broad reach and accelerate knowledge dissemination on the nexus of climate change and health
label: academic

text: The primary objective was to translate an existing face-to-face short course that only reached a few participants on climate change and health into globally accessible learning opportunities
label: academic

text: In the following, we share and comment on our lessons learned with the three MOOCs, with a focus on global teaching in the realm of climate change and health
label: academic

text: ConclusionsOverall, the three MOOCs attracted a global audience with diverse educational backgrounds, and a large number of participants from low-income countries
label: academic

text: Our experience highlights that MOOCs may play a part in global capacity building, potentially for other health-related topics as well, as we have found that our MOOCs have attracted participants within low-resource contexts
label: academic

text: MOOCs may be an effective method for teaching and training global students on health topics, in this case on the complex links and dynamics between climate change and health and may further act as an enabler for equitable access to quality education
label: academic

text: Assessment of spatial and temporal variation in the impacts of ozone on human health, vegetation, and climate requires appropriate metrics
label: academic

text: A key component of the Tropospheric Ozone Assessment Report (TOAR) is the consistent calculation of these metrics at thousands of monitoring sites globally
label: academic

text: Investigating temporal trends in these metrics required that the same statistical methods be applied across these ozone monitoring sites
label: academic

text: The nonparametric Mann-Kendall test (for significant trends) and the Theil-Sen estimator (for estimating the magnitude of trend) were selected to provide robust methods across all sites
label: academic

text: This paper provides the scientific underpinnings necessary to better understand the implications of and rationale for selecting a specific TOAR metric for assessing spatial and temporal variation in ozone for a particular impact
label: academic

text: The rationale and underlying research evidence that influence the derivation of specific metrics are given
label: academic

text: The form of 25 metrics (4 for model-measurement comparison, 5 for characterization of ozone in the free troposphere, 11 for human health impacts, and 5 for vegetation impacts) are described
label: academic

text: Finally, this study categorizes health and vegetation exposure metrics based on the extent to which they are determined only by the highest hourly ozone levels, or by a wider range of values
label: academic

text: The magnitude of the metrics is influenced by both the distribution of hourly average ozone concentrations at a site location, and the extent to which a particular metric is determined by relatively low, moderate, and high hourly ozone levels
label: academic

text: Hence, for the same ozone time series, changes in the distribution of ozone concentrations can result in different changes in the magnitude and direction of trends for different metrics
label: academic

text: Thus, dissimilar conclusions about the effect of changes in the drivers of ozone variability (e
label: academic

text: , precursor emissions) on health and vegetation exposure can result from the selection of different metrics
label: academic

text: Background: Anthropogenic global warming, interacting with social and other environmental determinants, constitutes a profound health risk
label: academic

text: This paper reports a comprehensive literature review for 1989–2013 (inclusive), the first 25 years in which this topic appeared in scientific journals
label: academic

text: It explores the extent to which articles have identified potentially catastrophic, civilization-endangering health risks associated with climate change
label: academic

text: Methods: PubMed and Google Scholar were primarily used to identify articles which were then ranked on a three-point scale
label: academic

text: Each score reflected the extent to which papers discussed global systemic risk
label: academic

text: Citations were also analyzed
label: academic

text: Results: Of 2143 analyzed papers 1546 (72%) were scored as one
label: academic

text: Their citations (165,133) were 82% of the total
label: academic

text: The proportion of annual papers scored as three was initially high, as were their citations but declined to almost zero by 1996, before rising slightly from 2006
label: academic

text: Conclusions: The enormous expansion of the literature appropriately reflects increased understanding of the importance of climate change to global health
label: academic

text: However, recognition of the most severe, existential, health risks from climate change was generally low
label: academic

text: Most papers instead focused on infectious diseases, direct heat effects and other disciplinary-bounded phenomena and consequences, even though scientific advances have long called for more inter-disciplinary collaboration
label: academic

text: Abstract Ethiopia is one of the most vulnerable countries experiencing drought and floods as a result of climate variability and change
label: academic

text: Climate change in the form of higher temperature, reduced rainfall, and increased rainfall variability reduces crop yield and threatens food security in low income and agriculture-based economies
label: academic

text: This study reviews impact of climate change and variability, and climate change adaptation strategies employed at farm level in response to perceived changes in temperature and precipitation
label: academic

text: Climate change negatively affects agriculture, nutrition, ground water availability, soil organic matter and soil quality, health conditions, growth and poverty
label: academic

text: The survey reveals that Ethiopian farmers adopt many strategies in response to climate change
label: academic

text: These strategies include “use of improved crop varieties,” “agroforestry practices,” “crop diversification,” “soil conservation practices,” “tree planting,” “off-farm activities,” “irrigation practices,” “adjusting planting dates,” “selling of assets,” “food aid,” and “permanent and temporary migration in search of employment” are the most important adaptation strategies by smallholder farmers
label: academic

text: However, “level of education,” “gender,” “age,” “wealth of the head of household,” “access to extension and credit,” “information and climate social capital,” “agroecological settings,” and “temperature” all influence farmer’s choices; “lack of information on adaptation methods,” “financial constraints,” and “lack of access to land” as main barriers to adapt climate change and variability
label: academic

text: Another investigator also revealed that farmers living in the dry lowland area perceived more change in climate than farmers in the wet lowland area
label: academic

text: Climate change impacts on the Canadian food system pose risks to human health
label: academic

text: Little attention has been paid to the climate change, food security, and human health nexus, resulting in a number of knowledge gaps regarding food system components that are most vulnerable to climate change
label: academic

text: The lack of understanding of key dynamics and possible future impacts challenges the ability of public health officials and partners in other sectors to prepare Canadians for future health risks
label: academic

text: A series of literature reviews were conducted to establish the relationship between climate change, food security, and human health, and to identify vulnerabilities within the Canadian food system
label: academic

text: Evidence suggests that key activities within the food system are vulnerable to climate change
label: academic

text: The pathways in which climate change impacts travel through the food system and affect the critical dimensions of food security to influence human health outcomes are complex
label: academic

text: Climate-related disruptions in the food system can indirectly impact human health by diminishing food security, which is a key determinant of health
label: academic

text: Human health may also be directly affected by the physical effects of climate change on the food system, primarily related to the impacts on nutrition and foodborne illnesses
label: academic

text: In this study, we propose a novel analytical framework to study and respond to the climate change, food security, and human health nexus
label: academic

text: This work is intended to help public health officials, researchers, and relevant stakeholders investigate and understand current and future risks, and inform adaptation efforts to protect the health of Canadians
label: academic

text: Climate change and climate-sensitive disasters significantly impact health
label: academic

text: Linking Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) and Climate Change Adaptation (CCA) is essential for addressing these ever present, complex and increasing risks
label: academic

text: Recent calls have been made to build these links in health
label: academic

text: However, there is a need to clearly articulate why linking DRR and CCA is important in health
label: academic

text: Furthermore, little is known about how DRR and CCA should be linked in health
label: academic

text: By extensively examining relevant literature, this review presents the current state of knowledge of linking DRR and CCA in health
label: academic

text: This includes the potential for maximising conceptual synergies such as building resilience, and reducing vulnerability and risk
label: academic

text: Additionally, technical and operational synergies are identified to link DRR and CCA in health, including: policy, Early Warning Systems, vulnerability and risk assessment, health systems strengthening, infrastructure resilience, disaster preparedness and response, and health impact pathways
label: academic

text: Public health actors have a central role in building these links due to their expertise, work functions, and experience in addressing complex health risks
label: academic

text: The review concludes with recommendations for future research, including how to better link DRR and CCA in health; and the opportunities, challenges and enablers to build and sustain these links
label: academic

text: Current day youth have an important role in climate activism, as the decisions and policies made now will have long lasting impacts on the climate and sustainability

text: PurposeThis paper aims to investigate farmers’ vulnerability to climate change and variability in the northern region of Ghana
label: academic

text: Design/methodology/approachThe study assessed the vulnerability of male-headed and female-headed farming households to climate change and variability by using the livelihood vulnerability index (LVI) and tested for significant difference in their vulnerability levels by applying independent two-sample-student’st-test based on gender by using a sample of 210 smallholder farming households
label: academic

text: FindingsThe results revealed a significant difference in the vulnerability levels of female-headed and male-headed farming households
label: academic

text: Female–headed households were more vulnerable to livelihood strategies, socio-demographic profile, social networks, water and food major components of the LVI, whereas male-headed households were more vulnerable to health
label: academic

text: The vulnerability indices revealed that female–headed households were more sensitive to the impact of climate change and variability
label: academic

text: However, female-headed households have the least adaptive capacities
label: academic

text: In all, female-headed farming households are more vulnerable to climate change and variability than male-headed farming households
label: academic

text: Research limitations/implicationsThe study recommends that female-headed households should be given priority in both on-going and new intervention projects in climate change and agriculture by empowering them through financial resource support to venture into other income-generating activities
label: academic

text: This would enable them to diversify their sources of livelihoods to boost their resilience to climate change and variability
label: academic

text: Originality/valueThis is the first study that examined the gender dimension of vulnerability of smallholder farmers in Ghana by using the livelihood vulnerability framework
label: academic

text: Female subordination in northern region of Ghana has been profound to warrant a study on gender dimension in relation to climate change and variability, especially as it is a semi-arid region with unpredictable climatic conditions
label: academic

text: This research revealed the comparative vulnerability of male- and female-headed households to climate change and variability

text: Significance Human-caused climate change could impact respiratory health, including asthma and allergies, through temperature-driven increases in airborne pollen, but the long-term continental pollen trends and role of climate change in pollen patterns are not well-understood
label: academic

text: We measure pollen trends across North America from 1990 to 2018 and find increases in pollen concentrations and longer pollen seasons
label: academic

text: We use an ensemble of climate models to test the role of climate change and find that it is the dominant driver of changes in pollen season length and a significant contributor to increasing pollen concentrations
label: academic

text: Our results indicate that human-caused climate change has already worsened North American pollen seasons, and climate-driven pollen trends are likely to further exacerbate respiratory health impacts in coming decades
label: academic

text: Airborne pollen has major respiratory health impacts and anthropogenic climate change may increase pollen concentrations and extend pollen seasons
label: academic

text: While greenhouse and field studies indicate that pollen concentrations are correlated with temperature, a formal detection and attribution of the role of anthropogenic climate change in continental pollen seasons is urgently needed
label: academic

text: Here, we use long-term pollen data from 60 North American stations from 1990 to 2018, spanning 821 site-years of data, and Earth system model simulations to quantify the role of human-caused climate change in continental patterns in pollen concentrations
label: academic

text: We find widespread advances and lengthening of pollen seasons (+20 d) and increases in pollen concentrations (+21%) across North America, which are strongly coupled to observed warming
label: academic

text: Human forcing of the climate system contributed ∼50% (interquartile range: 19–84%) of the trend in pollen seasons and ∼8% (4–14%) of the trend in pollen concentrations
label: academic

text: Our results reveal that anthropogenic climate change has already exacerbated pollen seasons in the past three decades with attendant deleterious effects on respiratory health

text: Abstract Neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) are a diverse group of diseases that continue to affect >1 billion people, with these diseases disproportionately impacting vulnerable populations and territories
label: academic

text: Climate change is having an increasing impact on public health in tropical and subtropical areas and across the world and can affect disease distribution and transmission in potentially diverse ways
label: academic

text: Improving our understanding of how climate change influences NTDs can help identify populations at risk to include in future public health interventions
label: academic

text: Articles were identified by searching electronic databases for reports of climate change and NTDs between 1 January 2010 and 1 March 2020
label: academic

text: Climate change may influence the emergence and re-emergence of multiple NTDs, particularly those that involve a vector or intermediate host for transmission
label: academic

text: Although specific predictions are conflicting depending on the geographic area, the type of NTD and associated vectors and hosts, it is anticipated that multiple NTDs will have changes in their transmission period and geographic range and will likely encroach on regions and populations that have been previously unaffected

text: There is a need for improved surveillance and monitoring to identify areas of NTD incursion and emergence and include these in future public health interventions

text: This systematic review of reviews was conducted to examine housing precarity and homelessness in relation to climate change and weather extremes internationally
label: academic

text: In a thematic analysis of 15 reviews (5 systematic and 10 non-systematic), the following themes emerged: risk factors for homelessness/housing precarity, temperature extremes, health concerns, structural factors, natural disasters, and housing
label: academic
